The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the republication of electronic editions of the Thomas Butts and John Linnell series of Blake’s water color illustrations of the Book of Job and the sketchbook of preliminary pencil drawings for his Job engravings. These three series were previously published in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images). With this republication, those functions now become available, along with our new Related Works feature giving access to related materials through active links on the work index pages and the Show Me menu on the object view pages. Blake’s Job engravings have been previously published with Image Search and Inote capabilities.
With this republication, the Archive now includes fully searchable reproductions of all four series of Job designs, among Blake’s greatest achievements as a visual artist. Thus, characters pictured in the designs, such as Bildad, Eliphaz, and of course Job’s wife, can be searched and located in all four series. The Archive’s Image Search menu also includes a great many lesser motifs, figure types, postures and gestures. In coming months, we will publish similarly updated versions of other works presently in Preview mode, including Blake’s nine series of water colors illustrating the poetry of John Milton.
The Archive recently added a new set of scholarly tools that should prove particularly useful when studying Blake’s Job designs. These tools, known collectively as our Related Works system, are designed to show relationships among works and individual objects in the Archive. They function at two levels. First, work index pages now include active links to related materials in the Archive. Thus, researchers can move easily from any given Job series to any other series. Second, the Show Me menu on object view pages now includes Related Works in the Archive. Like the work-level menu, this list includes active links to related designs and is meant to allow study of the related materials side by side. For example, researchers can move quickly from Blake’s engraving of Behemoth and Leviathan to its drawing in the sketchbook and study how Blake developed his design from preliminary sketch to finished engraving.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.
September 2006:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of the Linnell set of Blake's water color illustrations to The Book of Job and the sketchbook containing Blake's reduced drawings preparatory for the Job engravings. The sketchbook is reproduced complete and in color for the first time. These two important sets of Job illustrations join the Butts set of water colors and the engravings, both previously published in the Archive. Thus, the Archive now includes all four series of Job illustrations. The engravings are fully searchable. The Linnell set of water colors and the sketchbook are presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program).
Blake's pictorial engagements with The Book of Job extended over many decades. His first efforts were a small group of wash drawings of the mid-1780s showing Job in his misery with his wife and three friends. Another version of this subject appears among the emblem series that Blake sketched in his Notebook, but the composition appearing in the wash drawings culminated in the large intaglio etching/engraving, "Job," which Blake listed in his advertisement To the Public of 10 October 1793. This print may have stimulated Blake's chief patron, Thomas Butts, to commission a tempera painting, Job and His Daughters, c. 1799-1800 and, about six years later, a series of nineteen water colors illustrating the story of Job (the so-called "Butts set"). In 1821, Blake and his new patron John Linnell borrowed the water colors from Butts. Linnell traced the series and Blake colored them (the so-called "Linnell set"). Blake also added two more compositions to this later group and added versions of these same compositions to the earlier group, so that both sets now have twenty-one designs. The Linnell set led directly to his commission for the engravings. These began as a series of reduced sketches executed in 1823; the engravings themselves, with a title page added, were not finished and published until 1826.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Library of Congress, the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.objorder: 1-32The original order of all the leaves in this sketchbook cannot be determined definitively because the folded sheets of paper are now loose. The order presented here follows Butlin. The "plate" numbers referenced in the titles of individual designs and in the Editors' Notes are the plate numbers inscribed on Blake's engraved illustrations to *The Book of Job*.
objinfo.objsize: 23.5 x 14.5 cm. (the sketchbook's covers, bearing Objects 1-3, 31-32), 22.2 x 14.5 cm. (the sketchbook's internal leaves, bearing Objects 4-30)
objinfo.numberleaves: 34The internal leaves of the sketchbook, bearing Objects 4-30, are constituted by 15 sheets of paper, folded once through their short dimension to form a booklet of 30 leaves. Except for the leaf bearing Objects 24-25, the versos of these leaves are blank. 4 leaves toward the end of the sketchbook are blank on both rectos and versos. The covers of the sketchbook, bearing Objects 1-3 and 31-32, are comprised of two leaves from *Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley. . .Drawn, Engraved, and Published, by William Blake* (1802), folded once through their short dimension to create 4 leaves, 2 serving as the front covers and 2 serving as the back covers. The verso of the inner cover leaf at the beginning of the booklet, and both the recto and verso of the inner cover leaf at the end of the booklet, are blank. Only leaves bearing drawings and/or inscriptions are reproduced here, Objects 1-32.
objinfo.leafsize: 23.5 x 14.5 cm. (the sketchbook's covers, bearing Objects 1-3, 31-32), 22.2 x 14.5 cm. (the sketchbook's internal leaves, bearing Objects 4-30)
objinfo.medium: pencil (except for Object 3, a pen and ink inscription), with added pen and ink outlines (Objects 6-15, 17, 19, 2428, 29), water color washes (Objects 7-20, 22, 24, 26, 28, 29), and whiting (Objects 6, 7, 31)
objinfo.support: wove paper The paper of the sketchbook's internal leaves, bearing Objects 3-30, is unusually rough and fibrous.
objinfo.pennednumbers: Objects 7-24 are numbered 1-18, Object 24 numbered 18, Object 27 numbered 21, Object 28 numbered 19, Object 29 numbered 20, all top right in pencilThe inscribed pencil numbers, which accord with the numbers top right in the engravings of the same designs, are probably in a hand other than Blake's, possibly that of John Linnell or a member of his family.
objinfo.binding: loose sheets, but folded and contained within two paper covers
objinfo.stabholes: two holes, approximately 7.0 cm. from the top and 6.6 cm. apart

objnote.p: This outer front cover is made from a leaf of *Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley. . .Drawn, Engraved, and Published, by William Blake* (1802), folded once through its short dimension. The letterpress text is the bottom half of page 38.

lg.l: invThe pencil inscriptions on the recto of this outer front cover leaf of the sketchbook are mostly trial efforts at a WB (William Blake) signature or monogram. The exceptions are an Albrecht Durer monogram ("A" over "D"—see lines 3-4), perhaps inscribed as a model or precedent for the WB signatures, and the numerical calculations in lines 9-11 and 30-31. Butlin 557.I states that all the inscriptions were "probably done by the Linnell family." Their motivation for such an activity is unclear; one could understand their placing a single Blake signature on the cover to indicate the authorship of the drawings that follow, but why would anyone other than Blake practice a Blake signature over 30 times on the cover of a valuable sketchbook? There is at least a slight chance that these inscriptions are by Blake. The inscriptions on this recto of the outer front cover might have been written along with the similar inscriptions on the conjugate verso of the outer back cover (Object 32) before the sheet was folded.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A leaf from Hayley’s Ballads, containing verses 29-31 of “Ballad the Third,” has a list of the twelve apostles’ names written and numbered by Blake in the upper left corner. To the right of this list is a sketch of Job’s head and shoulders. Job faces away from the viewer with his head bent back. In the lower half of the leaf are indistinct pencil marks.

component.illusobjdesc: A sketch of Job facing away from the viewer appears in the upper center of the leaf. His hair is represented by long and short pencil strokes. His gown trails over what seems to be his shoulder. A long horizontal line may indicate that his left arm is raised; a much shorter line below and to the right of his head suggests that his right arm is also raised. He appears to have his head bent back; he may be looking upwards and slightly to the right. The distinguishing facial features that can be discerned are his forehead, nose, and right cheek. There may be an outline of his mustache as it connects to adjacent lines near his face, which suggest a flowing beard.

desc.objtitle: Two Studies for Plate 1: Job and His Family, Object 6 (Butlin 557.5)

objnote.p: The central drawing is a preliminary study for the central parts of the composition in Object 3 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*. The figure sketched lower right is a separate, detail study of the female figure (one of Job's daughters) kneeling right of Job in Object 7 of these drawings and Object 3 of the engravings. The verso of this leaf (Butlin 557.6) is blank. See Object 4 here for two preliminary detail studies for the female figure (one of Job's daughters) kneeling to the left of Job's wife in this design, and see Object 7 here for a more developed drawing of the whole composition. For sketches of leaves possibly related to the foliage on the central tree in this design, see Object 30. See Object 31 for two drawings of a dog's head that may be detail preliminary sketches, in reverse, for the dog with its head resting on a sheep in the center foreground of this design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the leaf is a sketch of Job and his family, detailed in its center but becoming increasingly faint as the image nears the margins. A large tree (perhaps an oak) with musical instruments in its branches rises behind Job and his wife, who have open books (perhaps Bibles) on their laps. Three daughters kneel around them. Six(?) other childen kneel nearby, three on the left and three on the right. Part of the sun appears above distant hills or mountains on the left; a cresent moon hovers above hills or mountains on the right. Two, possibly three, sheep lie in the foreground. In the lower right corner is an enlarged sketch of one of Job’s kneeling daughters (to the right of Job) with her arms crossed over her chest.

component.illusobjdesc: Job, gowned, bearded, old, and with long hair, sits surrounded by his family. He faces towards the viewer with an open book on his lap; he may be reading. His left hand holds the upper left corner of the book with fingers slightly spread. Both arms appear to be at his sides, resting on his lap (his right arm is obscured by the middle kneeling daughter). His left arm is slightly bent at the elbow.
Job’s wife, gowned and with long hair, sits to the left of Job. She has an opened book on her lap, and her hands are together in prayer, palms vertical. She faces forward and slightly to the right.
Job and his wife hold open books (perhaps Bibles) on their laps.

A large tree (perhaps an oak) rises behind Job and his wife. The upper trunk of the tree contains a few musical instruments. A few squiggle lines to the left and right of the upper reaches of the tree may indicate leaves.

Hung in the upper trunk of the large tree are outlines of musical instruments. As indicated by the engraving, from left to right they are a tambourine, a stringed instrument (possibly a mandolin), a triangular harp, and perhaps the outline of a horn.

A group of three figures, probably all males as in the engraving, appear to the left of the central tree. The left-most figure kneels; his right arm is bent upwards. He may be praying. He wears a gown and faces forward and to the right with his head tilted slightly to the left and down. His hair may be long. A faint hooked-shaped line that appears above and behind his head suggests a shepherd’s crook.

A group of three figures, probably all males as in the engravings, appear to the left of the central tree. The second and third figures from the left are kneeling in a similar fashion as the left-most figure. The head and shoulders of the second figure (from the left) suggest that he faces forward and to the right. Another hooked-shaped line appears above its head, thus resembling a second shepherd’s crook. The third figure (from the left) is only vaguely indicated by a cluster of lines right of the second figure's face.

One of Job's daughters kneels in prayer immediately to the left of Job and his wife. She wears a long gown; her hair is long and may in part be drawn back into a bun. Her body faces to the right, but her head is turned toward us and slightly down. Her eyes may be closed, or at least looking sharply downward. Her bare feet are prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels between her parents in the center of the design. Like her sister to the left, she may be praying. She is gowned and has long hair. We see her from behind, but her face is turned in profile to the left and slightly down. Her bare feet are prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels just to the right of Job and left of the group of three sons on the right. Like her sisters, she may be praying. She is gowned and has her arms crossed over her breast; the fingers of her right hand are spread apart slightly. She faces part-way between forward and to the left; her head is tilted slightly down. Her long(?) hair is gathered into a bun; her bare feet are prominent.

A group of three figures, probably all males as in the engraving, appear to the right of the central tree. The right-most figure is most clearly defined. With his head tilted back and facing left, he kneels in prayer with at least his left arm bent upward. He has short, curly hair and wears a gown. His bare left foot is prominent.

A group of three figures, probably all males as in the engraving, appear to the right of the central tree. The second and third figures next to the right-most figure appear to be kneeling as they face to the left.
A line of hills, with a larger mountain on the right, define the horizon.
A rising or setting sun appears just above the horizon in the left background.
A crescent moon appears in the sky on the right. The rim of the dark portion of the moon is also pictured.
Two, possibly three, sheep lie in the foreground below the human figures. At least two are lying prone and face each other.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job, his wife, and his sons and daughters sit and kneel in attitudes of prayer before a large, central tree (perhaps an oak). Job and his wife have open books (perhaps Bibles) on their laps; six sons hold shepherd's crooks (the son third from the right in the group on the right is without a shepherd’s crook). A large harp, a mandolin (or some such stringed instrument), a tambourine, and four horned instruments hang in the tree above the heads of Job and his wife. Seven sheep lie in the grassy foreground. Flocks of sheep lie or graze right and left of the figures; behind the sheep are (from left to right) a clump of trees, a Gothic building (probably a church), and a cluster of (two or three?) tents right of the central tree. Above the background hills and mountains are a radiant sun (left) that may be rising or setting, and a crescent moon (right).

component.illusobjdesc: Job's wife sits on the left side of the central tree, her hands together in prayer. She is gowned and faces forward, with eyes raised to the right; an open book (possibly a Bible) rests on her lap.

Job sits among his family on the right side of the central tree. He is long-haired, bearded, wears a gown, and faces forward with eyes raised. He holds an open book in his lap; the fingers of his left hand are slightly spread. Like most of the other figures in the scene, Job may be praying.

On the far left of the group of figures one of Job's sons kneels while holding a shepherd's crook. Like most of the other figures in the scene, he may be praying. He wears a long gown and his hair is short and curly. He faces half-way between forward and to the right, with his head lowered slightly. One bare foot is prominent; whether the left or the right is uncertain.

The figure second from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels and prays with his palms vertical and together. He is gowned and faces half-way between forward and to the right. His hair is short and a little curly; he holds a shepherd's crook under his left arm. His head is raised slightly.

The figure third from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels and prays. His hands may be clasped together, as in the engraving. He is gowned and faces half-way between forward and to the right. He is bearded and his hair is short. Like his brother to the left, he is holding a shepherd's crook under his left arm.

The figure fourth from the left, one of Job's sons, kneels. Like his two brothers to the left, he may be praying. This bearded and gowned figure faces forward and to the right. The top of a shepherd's crook is visible above the figure’s head.

One of Job's daughters, with long hair and wearing a gown, kneels in prayer between the group of four brothers on the left and Job's wife. Her body faces to the right, but her head is turned towards us and slightly down. Her bare feet are prominent. Her eyes are closed.

One of Job's daughters kneels between her parents in the center of the design. Like her sister to the left, she may be praying. She is gowned and has long hair. She is seen from behind; her bare feet are prominent.

One of Job's daughters kneels just to the right of Job and left of the group of three sons on the right. Like her sisters, she may be praying. She is gowned and her arms are crossed over her chest; the fingers of her right hand may be slightly spread. She faces left, with her head turned partly forward and tilted slightly down. She appears to be looking downwards. Her long hair is gathered into a bun. One foot is prominent; whether the left or the right is uncertain.

One of Job's sons kneels in prayer with his palms together on the far right in the group of kneeling figures on the right. He is gowned; his hair is short and curly. The top of a shepherd's crook appears above his head; he is probably holding it with his (right?) arm. He faces to the left and his bare left foot is prominent.

One of Job's sons, gowned and bearded, second from the right in the group of figures on the right. He has short, curly hair amd kneels in prayer, his hands clasped together and his fingers visible. He faces half-way between forward and to the left and appears to hold his shepherd's crook under his right arm.

One of Job's sons, gowned, bearded, and with short hair, kneels third from the right in the group of figures on the right. Like his brothers to the right, this figure’s arms appear to be bent upward in a posture suggestive of prayer. He faces half-way between forward and to the left.

The group of foreground animals includes (left to right), a ram and six sheep. All are lying prone and may be sleeping. The ram (lower left corner) displays looped and spiral-like horns. The animal third from the right might be a dog, as in the engraving.
A small mound of earth appears below the central tree and kneeling figures.
The upper center of the composition is anchored by a large and leafy tree, probably an oak.
A flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance on the left side of the composition. At least two are standing to graze.

A flock of sheep is pictured in the middle distance on the right side of the composition. The front-most sheep may be lying prone, while facing the right, but its head turned to the left. Second from the front is another sheep that may be lying prone or standing.
A small clump of leafy trees appears in the background between the left edge of the design and the large Gothic building.
A large Gothic building, perhaps a church, appears in the background on the left. It is decorated with a tower and spires. The building is probably made of stone.
Two or three tents appear in the middle distance right of the large tree.
A line of hills, with a larger mountain with a steep crag on the right, define the horizon.
Behind the mountains on the left, a rising or setting sun appears with a glow of radiance around it. Surrounding lines indicate beams of light.
A crescent moon appears in the sky on the right. As in Coleridge's "Dejection: An Ode," the dark portion of the moon is rimmed with a line of reflected light.

A group of seven musical instruments hang in the tree above the heads of Job and his wife. They are, from left to right, a tambourine, a mandolin (or some such stringed instrument), a horn with a looped, spiral-like body, a large triangular harp, two curved horns, and a trumpet.

desc.objtitle: Study for Plate 2: Satan Before the Throne of God, Object 8 (Butlin 557.9)

objnote.p: A few pencil lines above and below the design and in the left margin may indicate positions for inscriptions or a border design. The verso of this leaf (Butlin 557.10) is blank.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job sits with his family lower center, holding a book or tablet. His wife is to the left, holding an open book (possibly a Bible) on her lap. Four of Job's children are sitting or standing on the right. The figures are seated or reclining on what appear to be benches. A resting dog appears beneath the bench or benches. Two winged angels hover lower left; the front-most angel holds a scroll. Behind the family group are two trees; the tree on the right has a vine entwined around its trunk. A flock of sheep grazes in the left middle distance. Another complex figure group appears in the heavens above, partly contained within cloud bands left and right. At the top sits God with an open book on his lap. He may be pointing downwards toward Satan, who hovers, striding vigorously to the left, in flames. Also in the fire are slight indications of the faces of Job and his wife. Four angels hover on the left side of the group; one reaches toward (and perhaps offers an object before) God's throne-like chair, while another holds an open book. These figures are balanced by a group of four on the right, including an angel apparently placing an object before God.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits with his family lower center. His hair and beard are long; his left knee and the hem of his garment are prominent. He faces forward, but his head is turned slightly to the left. He may be looking at the hovering angels to the left. He holds a book or tablet between his left hand and left knee. His right hand may be holding the bottom of the book or tablet or gesturing downwards.
Job holds a book or tablet.

Job's wife, gowned and with long hair, sits to the left of her husband. She faces forward, with her head turned slightly to the right and downward. Her arms are bent slightly as she holds an open book (perhaps a Bible) on her lap.
Job's wife holds an open book (perhaps a Bible) on her lap.

Two winged and youthful angels hover lower left. The front-most angel is gowned, has long hair, and faces forward and slightly to the right. The left foot may be outlined beneath the drapery of his gown. As in the engraving, the angel may be holding a scroll.

Two winged and youthful angels hover lower left. The rear angel, almost covered by his companion, is gowned. His body faces forward and to the right, and one bare foot is visible beneath the hem of his gown. A few lines above his head hint at wings.
Beneath the two hovering angels is a shadow that is concentrated under them and grows fainter as it spans below Job and his wife.

One of Job's youthful sons sits, half-reclining, just to the right of his father. His hair is short and curly. He faces forward with his head turned slightly to the left; he may be nude except for the bit of drapery covering his lap. His right leg is bent at the knee before him, his left leg most likely extended to the right. His right foot is suggested by a dark patch of wash.

A second figure appears to the right of Job. In the engraving, this seated, half-reclining figure is female, and is one of Job's daughters. She faces forward, and may be gowned. A few lines suggest long hair.

A youthful and nude male stands, facing left, as the second figure from the right in the foreground. His right leg is bent at the knee, and his left arm is raised and bent at 45 degrees. His hair is short. He may be holding a book, as in the engraving, although such an object is only hinted at in this drawing.

A gowned figure stands at the edge of the right margin. The figure is partially hidden by the nude young man in front, so that only its head, shoulders, and long gown are visible. This figure, who does not appear in the engraving, is most likely a male, one of Job's sons.
A flock of sheep in the near middle-distance grazes on the grass between the hovering angels on the left and Job's wife.
Job and three members of his family sit or half-recline on bench-like seat under which a dog rests.
As is made clear by the engraving, a dog lies beneath the bench on which Job's children sit. The dog is lying down, and may be asleep.
Two trees, at least the one on the left bearing leaves, appear in the middle distance right of Job. The right-most tree has a vine entwined around its trunk.
Cloud bands, left and right, border the interior spaces of the upper part of the composition.

God, enthroned, sits at the highest point in the design. A halo-like area surrounds his body; his hair and beard are long. He holds (with his left hand) an open book on his lap; he may be pointing downward with his right hand.
God holds an open book on his lap.
God sits enthroned, on a chair or seat. There may be a plinth beneath his feet.
Four nude(?) angels hover to the left of God. The upper-most angel faces right and slightly down; his posture suggests that he may be bowing. We see only his head and back.
Four nude(?) angels hover to the left of God. The angel second from the top faces right and slightly down. He may be bowing. We see his right leg behind the third figure from the top.

Four nude(?) angels hover to the left of God. The third angel from the top faces right with his body facing partially forward and downward. His hair is short. His arms are extended horizontally towards the right. His posture suggests that he is bowing before God, and is either reaching toward God or has just offered an object, towards which he appears to be looking. His legs are together and his genitals are clearly visible.

Four nude(?) angels hover to the left of God. The lower-most angel is nude and faces to the right. His body is turned away from the viewer, and twists to the right, so that he see his face in profile. His right leg, which is extended backward, crosses behind his left at the calf. He has short, curly hair and holds an open book (separated leaves clearly visible) in his right hand. His buttocks are clearly visible.
Four nude(?) angels hover to the left of God. The lower-most angel is nude and faces to the right. He holds a book with leaves blown open as if by wind.
We see a head just below Satan's extended right arm. In the engraving, this is Job; the head may be either Job or his wife in this drawing.

Satan hovers in flames in the middle of the design. He strides energetically to the left, but with his head twisted up and to the right to look at God. His hair is short and curly, his body youthful and muscular. He is nude except for a wisp of flame(?) covering his genitals. His arms are raised, bent at the elbows, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. His mouth may be open and he may be speaking. His bare feet are prominent.
Satan hovers before flames in the middle of the design. The wavy lines beneath him may be either flames or a cloud band.
Four angels hover right of God and Satan. We see only the head and back of the top figure; he faces down and to the left and may be bowing before God.
Four angels hover right of God and Satan. We see only a part of the head and body of the second figure from the top. He faces down and to the left as if bowing before God.

Four angels hover right of God and Satan. The third figure from the top faces down and to the left, with his lower body turned toward the viewer; he may be bowing before God. He is nude, and his bare right foot is prominent. He reaches forward and to the left, possibly offering something in his hands, which he may be placing before God’s throne.

Four angels hover right of God and Satan. The front-most angel is nude and faces forward and to the left, with his upper body twisted to the right at the waist. His hair is short. His legs are extended to the right. His right arm is bent across his body, and his left arm may be bent upward. He may be holding something in his hands—a scroll in the engraving.

l.note: This number, written in pencil and preceded by a check mark, corresponds with the inscribed number on the engraving of the same design (Object 4 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*). The number is probably not in Blake's hand, but it may have been written by John Linnell or a member of his family.

desc.objtitle: Study for Plate 3: Job's Sons and Daughters Overwhelmed by Satan, Object 9 (Butlin 557.11)

objnote.p: A preliminary border design, possibly including reclining human figures lower left and right, is sketched in pencil on all four sides of the design. The verso of this leaf (Butlin 557.12) is blank.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design shows the destruction of Job's family at the hands of Satan. The background is filled with dark flames and, at the top, bolts of lightning. Below are falling architectural elements, including at least two columns, and steps. On and about these steps are, just above the bottom margin, a gowned female lying supine, perhaps dead, with a lyre under her left hand and a tambourine under her feet. In the near foreground on the right is a nude male in an upside-down cruciform posture. There may be a platter under his left hand, as in the engraving. The other figures in the lower half of the design are, from left to right, a group of three figures clearly terrified (we see only their heads and gesturing arms and hands); two females reaching (for succor?) toward the male to the right; a large central nude male (whose posture, reversed, suggests that of Laocoön in the famous classical sculpture) with a child on his left shoulder; and a group of four figures below the central male, all with upraised arms. A few lines hint at a second upside-down figure just within the lower right margin. Above, Satan grins maniacally as he rains fire on his victims from his outstretched hands. He is half-kneeling, legs crossed, on a stony block; his bat-like wings dominate the top of the design. Radiance and bolts of lightning frame his head.

component.illusobjdesc: The background of the design is filled with flames.
Bolts of lightning flash from behind Satan's head and body, and along his right side. Clouds of smoke, or perhaps storm clouds, surround him.

Satan, in the top third of the design, half-kneels on a large block, probably of stone. Another such block appears just right of his right foot. These are probably broken pieces of the house of Job's eldest son. They may be falling on the figures below.
Two falling columns (or two pieces of the same column), probably made of stone, indicate the destruction of the house of Job's eldest son. The upper-most column has a simple classical capital.
The figures in the lower part of the design are displayed on or about a series of (stone?) steps rising from left to right.
A tambourine rests beneath the feet of the supine woman just above the bottom margin of the design. A lyre rests beneath her left hand.

A gowned young woman—a member of Job's family now being destroyed—lies supine just above the lower margin of the design. Her long, curly hair is spread out on the ground, her visible leg is slightly bent at the knees, and her left arm is at her side. A tambourine rests beneath her bare left foot; a lyre rests below her left hand. Her head is bent back; she may be dead.

A male hangs upside down in the lower right corner of the design. His eyes are closed(?); he appears to be dead. His arms, raised at 135 degrees relative to his body, suggest a cruciform position. His body is twisted slightly to the left, and his legs, which may be crossed, are bent over the step.
A few lines, including a circle, just within the lower right margin of the design may be the beginnings of a second upside-down figure, as in the engraving.

A group of three figures (probably females, as in the engraving) in the middle distance are left-most in the composition. We see only their heads, arms, and upper bodies. The figure farthest to the left twists her head up, back, and to the right. Her right arm is bent over her head; her left arm is bent, extended across her body, and raised at 135 degrees. Her palms are vertical; the palm of her right hand faces out, and her fingers may be spread.

A group of three figures (probably females, as in the engraving) in the middle distance are left-most in the composition. We see only their heads, arms, and upper bodies. The figure second from the left faces forward and right with her head up. She may have long hair.

A group of three figures (probably females, as in the engraving) in the middle distance are left-most in the composition. We see only their heads, arms, and upper bodies. The figure third from the left faces forward and right with her head up. Her mouth may be open in an expression of pain or terror.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure. They both raise their arms at 135 degrees with fingers spread toward the male, who appears to be helping them to rise and climb the steps. The front-most figure in this group faces to the right with her head bent back and her mouth open in an expression of pain or fear. Her right leg is drawn up and bent beneath her as she kneels on a step; her left leg is extended backward and bent at the knee. Her right arm is raised and held at its elbow by he central male. Her feet are prominent beyond her gown’s hem. Both feet may be on tiptoe.

Two young, long-haired, and gowned females are pictured immediately to the left of the central male figure. They both raise their arms at 135 degrees toward the male, who appears to be helping them to rise and climb the steps. The female figure just to the right of and above the kneeling female in the foreground reaches upward with her palms raised vertically and her fingers spread. Her left(?) leg is bent at the knee as she climbs upward; her right(?) leg is extended backwards. She faces upward and to the right with her head bent back and her mouth open. Her expression suggests pain or terror.

A figure (probably female, as in the engraving), with her left arm raised vertically, appears between the central male's right leg and the steps just to the right. We see only her head, upper body, and raised arm and hand. She faces forward. Her gesture suggests some mixture of pain and terror.

A group of four figures (probably female, as in the engraving) is pictured below the left foot of the central male figure. They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The leftmost figure is probably seen from behind, with its arms raised vertically. It may be grasping the stone steps, perhaps in order to climb upward.

A group of four figures (probably female, as in the engraving) is pictured below the central male figure. They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The figure second from the left, who appears to be nude, is seen from behind. The figure's head is turned upward and to the right, and her body is twisted. Her hair may be long. She may be grasping the stone steps with her hands, perhaps in order to climb upward.

A group of four figures (probably female, as in the engraving) is pictured below the central male figure. They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The figure third from the left is seen from behind with her arms raised vertically to grasp the two uppermost steps. She may trying to climb upward.

A group of four figures (probably female, as in the engraving) is pictured below the central male figure. They reach upward, as though seeking aid from the male. The figure left of the upside-down male faces forward, her head tilted back and with her arms raised vertically and her hands crossed over her head.

A youthful and muscular male dominates the center of the lower half of the design. He stands and faces forward, with his left leg bent sharply at the knee to position his foot on a raised step. His right leg is extended to the left. Both feet are on tiptoe. He may be attempting to climb the steps to the right. His upper body and neck are twisted to the left; he may be looking at the females to the left. His posture echoes that of Laocoön, reversed, in the famous classical sculpture group. He is nude except for a bit of drapery that extends along the right side of his chest and covers his genitals. He extends his right arm downward to grasp the elbow of the female to the left. His left arm is bent upward to hold a child sitting on his left shoulder. The fingers of his left hand may be spread apart. His hair is short and curly.

A young child or infant with short hair sits on the shoulder of the central male figure. We see the child from behind, with its head twisted sharply to the left so that it faces us. The child's mouth is slightly open, possibly in an expression of fear. The child's extended left arm reaches to the left, and appears to be grasping the hair of the male with the left hand. The child appears to be wearing a diaphanous gown with drapery, which makes its buttocks prominent. Its right leg dangles below the central male’s left bicep, making the bare right foot prominent.

A nude Satan with bat-like wings dominates the top of the design. He squats, crouches, or half-kneels, with legs sharply bent, on some stony blocks, his left foot crossing over his right calf. His arms are extended outward from his body at 45 degrees, with fingers spread apart and flames issuing from his hands and fingertips (palms facing down). His hair is short and curly. He faces forward, with his head twisted down and to the right. Lightning and radiance(?) flash around him. A slight, and no doubt sardonic, smile indicates his pleasure in destruction.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Sharp lines indicative of lightning bolts dominate the top border design. The left and right margins appear to contain clouds billows of smoke, as in the engraving. The bottom border design has a rough sketch, possibly of a landscape.

component.illusobjdesc: Sharp lines indicative of lightening bolts dominate the top border design. The curving lines in the left and right margins may indicate clouds or smoke, as in the engraving. The border designs appear to reflect the sky behind Satan in the central sketch.
The wavy, sketchy lines in the lower marginal design might suggest a landscape of hills or mountains. Curling lines left and right perhaps hint at clouds.

l.note: This number, written in pencil and preceded by a check mark, corresponds with the inscribed number on the engraving of the same design (Object 5 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*). The number is probably not in Blake's hand, but it may have been written by John Linnell or a member of his family.

desc.objtitle: Study for Plate 4: The Messengers Tell Job of His Misfortune, Object 10 (Butlin 557.13)

objnote.p: The verso of this leaf (Butlin 557.14) is blank.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A messenger runs, left to right, toward Job and his wife to tell them of the destruction of their family at Satan's hands. He wears a gown covering his lower body, waist to knees, and strides energetically towards the couple. Job raises his hands as if in prayer; his wife lifts her clasped hands above her head. A ram grazes far right, below the (stony?) seat or bench on which Job (and his wife?) sit. A tree rises along the right margin and extends its branches and leaves along the top margin of the sketch. Two stone pillars form the background for Job and his wife; to the left are two grazing sheep. The sky contains dark clouds, perhaps suggesting a coming storm. Another messenger, wearing a hat and holding a staff, strides energetically to the left in the middle background. A few vertical lines to the left of this second messenger will become a building in the engraving. A mountain dominates the horizon between Job’s wife and the messenger. The foreground, raised into a slight mound, appears to be partly covered with grass because of the yellow-green tinting. There may be mountainous ridges on the horizon far left.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits on the right. He is gowned, with his arms bent upward, hands together, and head bent back so that he looks up. His posture suggests that he may be praying. His long beard and hair cascade over his upper body, and his bare left foot is barely visible beneath the hem of his garment.

A youthful and muscular male messenger runs in from the left side of the design and toward Job and his wife. He strides dramatically, legs spread; his right arm reaches back and points horizontally to the left, and his left arm is raised to the right at 135 degrees. The fingers of his right hand is slightly spread apart, and the palm of the left hand faces up and out. His hair stands on end at the back of his head because of his speed. His mouth may be slightly open; he may be speaking as he approaches. His facial features suggest a mixture of grief and fear. His gown covers his body only from the waist to just above his knees, comparable to a skirt. His body faces forward, with his head turned partly to the right. His bare feet are prominent.

A second male messenger, who is seen between the legs of the large messenger in the foreground, strides energetically to the left. He wears a hat. His body faces to the left but his upper body is turned toward the viewer; his face turns forward towards the right. Both arms are bent, his right in front of him to hold a staff, his left behind his back. His legs are bent at the knee, with the left leg bent forward and the right leg bent back.
Two sheep graze in the middle distance at the center of the design. Half of their bodies are covered by the stone pillar to the right.
Behind Job and his wife are two pillars, probably made of stone. They form a wall-like background for the two seated figures.
Job sits on a (stone?) chair. We do not see what his wife sits on; perhaps this is a bench-like seat that can accommodate two.
A ram, with a prominent and looping horn, grazes lower right. We see only his neck, head, and perhaps one foreleg.
The foreground rises from lower left to right to form a slight mound on which the principal figures are disposed.
The yellow-green tinting below the left foot of the foreground messenger suggests grass.
A large tree, perhaps an oak as in the engraving, grows up the right margin and spreads its large leaves just below the top margin.
A mountain or mountains rise in the middle of the design between the messenger and the columns.
The ridges of hills and/or distant mountains form the horizon on the left side of the design.
The sky contains washes and indications of clouds. The dark sky might be suggestive of Job’s impending downfall or suggestive of a storm.
A few faint lines, lower left, are the only indication in the sketch of what will be a building, possibly a church, in the engraving.

l.note: This number, written in pencil and preceded by a check mark, corresponds with the inscribed number on the engraving of the same design (Object 6 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*). The number is probably not in Blake's hand, but it may have been written by John Linnell or a member of his family.

desc.objtitle: Study for Plate 5: Satan Going Forth from the Presence of the Lord, Object 11 (Butlin 557.15)

objnote.p: The verso of this leaf (Butlin 557.16) is blank.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job and his wife sit side by side on a stone bench in the lower portion of the design. Job's wife's right hand rests on her lap as she leans on Job. Her left hand holds his upper right arm. Job holds an object in his right hand, possibly half a loaf of bread, as in Object 7 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*. With his left hand he gives another object (possibly a half-loaf of bread) to an old man with a crutch and a dog. Behind the recipient of Job's charity is a winged angel. At least one other winged angel (possibly with the outline of another angel's head and upper body to the right) hovers on the left. The near foreground is grassy. The middle distance contains a grassy hill and what may be bushes or trees. On the left is a structure suggestive of a Druid trilithon. The horizon on the left is defined by distant mountains with clouds above. The upper portion of the design portrays several dramatic figures, particularly Satan, who hovers below God and above Job's head. He is nude. Flames ascend to the right near Satan's extended arms and legs. He holds a vial in his right hand, perhaps indicative of pestilence, over Job. On the left, four(?) figures hover among flames, probably angels although without wings. On the right, five more angels are similarly arranged in the ascending flames. Smoke, or perhaps clouds, encircle Satan and these angelic figures. In the center of this oval composition, God sits (left leg extended downwards) on a stone(?) throne, raised on a plinth. He faces forward. An oval of radiance surrounds his head and upper body.

component.illusobjdesc: Job, gowned and bearded with long hair, sits at the center of the lower portion of the design. He faces forward, with his head turned a little to the right, and leans slightly in the same direction. His bent right arm cradles an object. With his left arm, which is extended horizontally, he gives the beggar an offering out of his left hand. His knees are prominent, as is the hem of his garment.

Job holds two objects; one rests in his lap, held by his right hand, the other is held in his left hand. Both objects may be half-loaves of bread, as in Object 7 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*.

Job's wife, gowned and with long hair, sits beside him. She leans toward her husband and her left hand may be holding his upper right arm, as in Object 7 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*. Her right arm is bent, and her right hand may be resting in her lap. Her knees are prominent, as is the hem of her garment.

A gowned and winged angel hovers near the lower left margin. His arms may be crossed and bent upward, or his hands may be together in prayer, as in Object 7 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*. The hem of his garment trails beneath his feet. The sketchy outline of the head and upper body of a second angel (or an alternative position for the front-most angel) appears just to the right of the front-most angel.

A gowned and winged angel hovers near the lower right margin, facing to the left. A faint halo of radiance(?) may surround the angel's head. His arms may be bent upward, and his hands may be together in prayer, as in Object 7 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*. The hem of the angel's garment trails beneath his feet.

A beggar, hunched over and old, reaches out his bent left arm to receive an object (probably a small loaf of bread, as in Object 7 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*) from Job. The beggar has long hair, and leans on a crutch. A thin leash extends from the dog toward the old man on the right. The looped handle of the leash may be on the middle of the old man's left forearm. He may be blind, as suggested in Object 7 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*.
A dog, head down and perhaps sniffing the ground, appears just to the right of Job. A thin leash extends from the dog's neck toward the old man on the right.
Job and his wife sit on a bench or seat of some sort, probably made of stone. The rectangular object right of Job, under his extended left arm, may be part of the bench.
Green washes indicate grass in the foreground. A low hill rises to the left of Job and his wife.
Hills and mountains dominate the landscape background behind Job and his wife. There appears to be a mountain peak in the left far distance.

Left of Job's wife, a structure that resembles a stone trilithon appears in the middle distance. To the left of this structure is a fragment of what may at least one more pillar. The scene is suggestive of ruins.

God sits, enthroned, in the top center of the design. He is old and bearded, has long hair, and wears a gown. His bare feet are be prominent. His left leg, slightly bent at the knee, extends downward; his right leg is bent sharply at the knee and drawn up toward his torso. He faces forward but looks down and to the right. He holds objects in his hands; in Object 7 of Blake's engravings for *The Book of Job*, these are a book (right hand) and a scroll (left hand). An aura of radiance forms a backdrop for his head and upper body.
God appears to be holding objects in his hands. These may be a book (right hand) and a scroll (left hand), as in Object 7 of Blake's illustrations of The Book of Job.
God sits, enthroned, on a chair or seat of some sort. Its rounded arms can be seen left and right of his forearms.
God's throne and both his feet rest on a three-step plinth, probably made of stone.

Satan, a youthful male, hovers (or flies rapidly) beneath God. He is nude. His hair is short. The position of his limbs suggests dramatic movement, perhaps descending or curving from right to left. He faces forward, with his head twisted upward toward God. His left leg is extended up and to the right; his right leg is bent sharply at the knee and drawn up toward his upper right thigh. His genitals are visible. desc.objtitle: Study for Plate 14: When the Morning Stars Sang Together, Object 20 (Butlin 557.33)

objnote.p: The motifs lower right, below the words "done by" are, from left to right, a horizontal line (just possibly a crude representation of a pencil or engraving tool), a hand, possibly a capital letter "B," an eye and eyebrow, and a circle or globe with two dots just beyond its circumference, the dots positioned on a diagonal axis rising from lower left to upper right. This is probably an emblematic indication that the design was "done by" the hand and eye of Blake. The verso of this leaf (Butlin 557.34) is blank.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The complex design is divided by cloud bands into three sections. In the top section are stars and four youthful and winged angels. They may be nude, although the shaded regions on their bodies may indicate gowns (or tights); their overlapping arms are raised at 135 degrees. In light of the title in the engraving ("When the morning Stars sang together..."), these figures are probably personifications of the stars. The middle section is anchored by the ancient figure of God kneeling in the center of the design. His arms are outstretched horizontally with palms down. Beneath God's right arm is a figure hovering with arms extended horizontally over the outlines of (four?) horses. He may be the sun god Apollo, as is more clearly the case in the engraving of this design. Beneath God's left arm is a figure with her arms extended horizontally towards the right. The crescent moon affixed above her head identifies her as a moon goddess, probably Diana or Hecate. Job and his wife sit or kneel in the lowest section of the design. On the right are Job's three friends.

component.illusobjdesc: A horizontal band of cloud appears behind and on each side of God's extended arms, supporting the four angels from beneath. Two further narrow and vertical bands of clouds are pictured right and left of the leftmost and rightmost angels.

A prominent cloud band separates God (center of the design) from the human figures of Job, his wife, and his three friends, seated below. The clouds descend toward the ground in the right and left margins to form an arch-like appearance.
There are twelve stars in the sky. Two of these stars are directly above the angels' heads on the left and three are between the angels at knee-level.

In the top section are stars and four youthful and winged angels. All have their arms raised and overlapping at 135 degrees. Their hands are raised, with palms turned upward. They face forward, and may be striding forward. The angels may be nude, although shading on their bodies may indicate gowns. In light of the title of the engraving ("When the morning Stars sang together . . ."), these figures are probably personifications of the stars.

God—ancient, gowned, and bearded with long, flowing hair—anchors the center of the composition. He sits, squats, or kneels on a cloud band, with his right leg pulled up toward his body (as a result, his right knee is prominent). He faces forward, with arms outstretched horizontally and palms down. A halo, possibly formed by the cloud band above his head, surrounds his head.

A youthful and nude male with arms raised horizontally, palms out, appears below God's right arm. He may be pushing against the clouds he touches with both hands. He faces forward and to the left, with his torso bent forward. A halo, or perhaps the disc of the sun, may appear behind his head as seen in Object 16 of the engravings. He would seem to be hovering on the back of one of the horses pictured beneath him. A line extending above and to the right of his left shoulder suggests a wing; other such lines above his right arm may also be a wing. Given all these attributes and emblematic associations, this is very probably a sun god, perhaps Apollo, as in the engraving of this design.
Four(?) horses, charging to the left in serried rank, appear beneath the youthful figure under God's right arm. The front-most horse’s leg is raised in prideful manner.

A winged and gowned female appears below God's left arm. She faces to the right, with her arms extended horizontally before her. The sideways crescent moon affixed above her head identifies this figure as a moon goddess, perhaps Diana or Hecate.
A confused cluster of lines appear beneath the outstretched arms of the moon goddess below God's left arm. In the engraving of this design, these are serpents.
A crescent moon floats in the night(?) sky on the head of the female figure below God's left arm.

Job's wife sits or kneels lower left. She is gowned, with long hair, and faces forward with her head turned upward to look at God. Her arms are bent at the elbows with her palms together in a posture suggestive of prayer.

Job sits on the ground, the second figure from the left. He is gowned; his left knee is drawn up toward his torso, making his left foot visible beneath the hem of his garment. He faces forward, with his head bent back to look upward toward God. His arms are crossed over his chest. He is, as usual, old and bearded, with long hair as seen in the engravings.

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. If they are arranged as in the engraving, they are, from front to back, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. They all appear to be wearing gowns as they kneel or sit. The front most figure kneels, with its right knee drawn up to his chest ands his left arm bent at 45 degrees. We may also be able to discern the knee of the second figure, whose leg is similarly bent. All three probably face up and to the left and may be looking at God.

The motifs lower right, below the words "done by" are, from left to right, a horizontal line (just possibly a crude representation of a pencil or engraving tool), a hand, possibly a capital letter "B," an eye and eyebrow, and a circle or globe with two dots just beyond its circumference, the dots positioned on a diagonal axis rising from lower left to upper right. This is probably an emblematic indication that the design was "done by" the hand and eye of Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God, at the top center of the design, appears to lean on a cloud band that fills the night sky. Winged and gowned angels in attitudes of prayer frame the upper left and right portions of the design. The cloud band descends behind the angels and stops near the beginning of the bottom hemisphere of the circle or sphere in the lower portion of the design. Job, his wife, and three friends (Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar) kneel on the ground between God and the sphere and look down toward it. The Behemoth (above) and the Leviathan (below) within the circle or sphere are accompanied by reeds and a frothy wave of the sea in which Leviathan disports.

component.illusobjdesc: God—old, possibly bearded, and long haired—anchors the top center of the design. A halo arcs over his head and shoulders. He faces forward, but we see only his shoulders, arms, and head. His body is obscured by the cloud band on which he leans, with the upper part of his right arm resting over the band. He reaches downward with his left arm, in a gesture very similar to the figure's on the frontispiece to *Europe*, and points downward with his extended left hand and possibly his left index finger.

A cloud band circumscribes much of the design. At the top, it extends below, and perhaps supports, God, and descends in both the right and left margins, ending roughly at the midpoint of the top half of the circle or sphere on the left, and near the mid-point of the entire circle or sphere on the right.
Job, his wife and friends (the five figures below God), apparently kneel on the ground.

Two hovering angels, winged and gowned, frame God in the upper reaches of the design. The angel on the left faces to the right, with his arm bent at the elbow. His hands may be together in prayer. His lower right leg and foot are visible among the drapery trailing from his gown.

Two hovering angels, winged and gowned, frame God in the upper reaches of the design. The angel on the right faces to the left. The angel's arms may be bent upwards in the attitudes of prayer as seen in the engraving.

Five figures appear beneath God. The figure farthest left is most likely Job's wife as seen in the engraving. This figure sits or kneels in a contracted posture just to the left of a larger figure, probably Job. Her upper body leans forward and she faces to the right and forward. Her arms may be crossed over her chest or resting in her lap.

Five figures appear beneath God. The figure second from the left is most likely Job as seen in the engraving. Job kneels or sits in a contracted posture. He faces forward and down, with his arms crossed over his chest. He is probably looking down at the beasts to which God points.

Job's three friends kneel or sit just right of God's downward-reaching arm. If they are arranged as in the engraving, they are (from right to left) Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. All three may be looking at the beasts below. The front most figure leans forward, facing down and to the left, in a decidedly contracted posture. His left arm is bent sharply at the elbow, with his upper left arm close to his chest. All three are probably gowned with their knees prominent.
The great beasts, Behemoth and Leviathan, are pictured within a circle, sphere, or globe.

Behemoth is the upper-most of the two biblical beasts pictured within a circle or sphere. He stands (or possibly strides) facing towards the left, with his head turned partly forward. The Behemoth's large left ear is anthropomorphic; large teeth or tusks extend from his partly-open mouth. His spine and vertebrae are clearly pictured, as are his tail and ribs.

Leviathan is the lower of the two biblical beasts pictured within a circle or sphere. He is a giant sea-serpent with two sets of large fangs and additional rows of smaller fang-like teeth filling his partly-open mouth. His crested head faces up, while his intermittently spiky body loops to the left.
Reeds(?) frame the left midsection of the circle or globe.
Behemoth seems to stand on the ground, perhaps on the shore of the sea in which Leviathan wreathes.
Leviathan wreathes in the sea. A frothy wave breaks just below him.
The sky above and below the cloud band in the upper portion of the sketch includes at least ten circles that may indicate stars in a night sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God sits, apparently enthroned on a plinth or at the top of steps, at the top center of the design. He holds an open book on his lap; he raises his right hand, palm out, in a sign of blessing. A cloud on the left, and possibly another on the right, are sketched above the two large angels who hover nearby (right and left margins). Below, Satan falls headlong with bolts of lightning into the fires of hell below. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow-devils and as the fallen selves of Job (right) and his wife (left) as seen in the engraving. On the ground lower left, Job and his wife kneel, beholding the falling Satan. Job's three friends kneel on the right, aghast at the vision.

component.illusobjdesc: God sits, apparently enthroned on a plinth, at the top center of the design. He holds an open book on his lap; he raises his right hand, palm out and fingers spread, in a sign of blessing. He is old, with long hair and perhaps a beard, and wears a flowing gown. He faces forward, but leans and looks to the left. His knees are prominent, as is the hem of his garment.
God sits, apparently enthroned, above a plinth or at the top of stairs.
A cloud is pictured left of God's head; a few lines and smudges hint at a cloud right of his head. God holds an open book on his lap.

A large, winged, and gowned (male?) angel hovers on the upper left side of the design. His body faces to the right and his right arm appears to be bent upward, suggesting prayer. The angel's knee and right foot are visible among the drapery of his gown.

A large, winged, and gowned (male?) angel hovers on the right side of the design. His left leg is extended backward and probably bent slightly at the knee, and his body faces away from the viewer. The angel's left foot is visible among the drapery of his gown.
There may be tongues of flame below God; below them is a vision of Satan and two other figures (possibly Job and his wife).
Bolts of lightning appear below and on the left and right of Satan's head. Under his head are flames (of hell?).

Satan appears as the central figure falling (in flames?) below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (on the right?) and his wife (on the left?). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. The figure on the left has its head down, with its arms bent at the elbows; this figure may be clutching its head with both hands. It is seen from behind with its legs bent sharply at the knees and pulled up behind its torso; both feet are prominent.

Satan appears as the central figure falling (in flames?) below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (on the right?) and his wife (on the left?). Satan is seen from the front, with his arms bent behind his head as he falls upside down into the abyss with the other two figures. His legs are spread slightly apart, with he left leg extended and the right leg bent. His nude body is slightly twisted to the left.

Satan appears as the central figure falling (in flames?) below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (on the right?) and his wife (on the left?). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. The (nude?) figure on the right has its head down and upper body twisted slightly to the left. The figure's right arm appears to be bent over its head, which may suggest that the figure's arms are wrapped around its head and perhaps crossed. The figure is seen from behind, with legs bent at the knees and pulled up toward the torso. The figure's buttocks are prominent.

Job kneels, lower left. He is old, with long hair and a beard. He faces forward and to the right, with his head turned upward to view the vision of the falling figures. He is partly nude, with a loincloth covering his lap. His arms are at his side, with his right hand down, palm facing down and fingers spread. This gesture may suggest awe or surprise.

Job's wife kneels, lower left, just right of her husband, on whose shoulder she leans. She is gowned. Her left arm is crossed over her chest. She faces forward, with her head bent back and looking towards the vision of the falling figures.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner of the design. If they are arranged as in the engraving, these are Zophar (front-most), Bildad (head only), and Eliphaz (far right). The front-most figure appears to be gowned, and his left foot is prominent. He is kneeling. We see him from behind, with his body twisted to the right. Along with Job and his wife; he appears to be surprised or frightened by the vision. The other two figures are only suggested. They would appear to be a head only, and below him the head and body of the third friend. His head may be twisted to the left, with his body facing to the right and his right arm bent upward toward his head. All three may be looking upward toward the vision of the falling figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God stands on the left, his arms raised to bless Job and his wife who kneel before him, their hands clasped in prayer. On the right are Job's three friends; they turn away and cover their faces as though hiding from God's radiance, which is indicated by the circular lines and hints of shading surrounding God and the other figures. A distant hill or mountain, or, alternatively, a dark cloud, defines the background on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: God, gowned and magisterial, stands on the left and bends forward to reach down and bless Job and his wife. His hair is long; he may be bearded. He faces to the right, with his arms raised horizontally and the fingers of his right hand spread apart. He may be touching, or almost touching, Job's head. He may be looking down at Job and his wife. God's bare right foot appears at hem of his gown. Curving lines left and right suggest the burst of radiance we see in the engraving.
A circular outline with a few spiky perpendicular lines and hints of shading may suggest the burst of radiance surrounding God that we see in the engraving. The beams extend upwards and to the right.

Job's wife sits or kneels to the right of God, just beneath his extended left hand. She is gowned. She faces right, with her head turned a bit up and toward the viewer; she may be looking up at God. Her arms are bent at the elbows, with her hands together, as if in prayer.

Job kneels under God's extended right hand. He is old and bearded with long hair, and appears to be wearing a gown. His arms are down and rest upon his lap; his hands seems to be clasped in an attitude of prayer. He faces to the left and forward.

Job's three gowned friends huddle together in contracted postures, as seen in the engraving, apparently surprised or frightened by God's presence. They sit or squat, turning away from God and facing down and to the right. If arranged as in the engraving, they are (from front to back) Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. The front-most figure appears to have his right arm bent upward, possibly clutching his head with his right hand. All three friends probably wear gowns.
The background on the right includes a hill or mountain, or, alternatively, a dark cloud.
A small mound, apparently of earth, is pictured in the lower left corner of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job stands, with his back to us, before a stone altar, above which rises a triangular-shaped flame. His cruciform posture, with arms extended a little above the horizontal, suggests a self-sacrifice. Job's wife kneels in an attitude of prayer on the left. Job's three friends kneel with heads bowed on the right. A few lines on either side of the flame, apparently extending downward from the top center of the design, suggest beams of light. A few lines suggesting distant mountains define the far horizon.

component.illusobjdesc: Job stands, with his back to us, before a stone altar, above which rises a triangular-shaped flame. His cruciform posture, with arms extended a little above the horizontal, suggests a self-sacrifice Job is giving to his God, and, perhaps, a type of spiritual ecstasy. He is gowned, and has long hair. His palms may face up, and his fingers may be spread apart. His right leg (especially noticeable at his calves) appears to be slightly bent and extended a bit behind him, probably making his right foot balance on tiptoe (as seen in the Linnell watercolor and engravings). His head is turned to the left and tilted slightly upward. The flowing hem of his garment is prominent.
Job’s wife kneels in prayer just to the left of her husband. She faces away and to the right, with her head bowed and her right arm raised in an attitude of prayer. Her hair is probably long.

Job's three friends kneel lower right. If they are arranged as in the engraving, these are Bildad in the center and Eliphaz and Zophar on either side of him. Even in the engraving, there is insufficient evidence to distinguish between these two. Like Job's wife, they may be praying. Their postures are somewhat contracted as they bend forward with heads down. They are depicted from behind and appear to be wearing flowing gowns.
A large altar, probably made of stone, stands behind of Job.

A large, triangular-shaped flame rises from the altar in front of Job. This is probably a burning sacrifice Job is offering to his God. Diagonal lines on either side of the flame, apparently extending downward from the top center of the design, suggest beams of light.
The horizon is defined by a few lines suggesting distant mountains just below Job's arms. Washes in the sky above hint at clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits in a patriarchal position, arms raised horizontally, above his daughters in the center of the sketch. He probably faces forward.
Job's three daughters sit or squat below him, huddled together with one in front and one on each side.

In the top half of the sketch, God appears to hover before the tree top in a whirlwind that includes human figures, probably angels. Two large nude figures descend headfirst framing God’s whirlwind. The circle top left may be the head of an additional figure. A blue wash indicates the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: God, hovering in the upper reaches of the design, is old and bearded. Human figures, probably angels, surround him in a whirlwind. He faces forward with his arms raised horizontally. His palms are up and out; his fingers may be spread. He may be gowned and probably has long hair.

The whirlwind surrounding God appears to be composed in part of (seven?) human figures, probably angels. Only their heads are clearly indicated. Two nude(?) figures descend lower left and right, their bodies conforming to the lower boundary of God's whirlwind.
God hovers within a whirlwind, composed in part of human figures, probably angels.
There may be an additional figure, possibly an angel, upper left. Only the head is clearly indicated.
male

A large nude figure hovers to the left of God's whirlwind. He(?) descends downwards as his body curves with the whirlwind. His arms extended and he may be holding something in his hands. His legs are together and his buttocks are prominent. He appears to have short hair.

A large nude(?) figure hovers to the right of God's whirlwind. He(?) descends downwards as his body curves with the whirlwind. His arms are extended and he may be holding something in his hands. His legs are together, and he appears to have short hair.
Diagonal lines suggesting radiance or beams of light seem to emanate from the whirlwind, particularly lower left just above the heads of the figures standing below.
A great oak(?) tree anchors the center of the design. Large branches may extend left and right of God's whirlwind. Job and his wife are seated before the trunk.
Job’s wife sits to the left of Job. She wears a gown. Her arms are bent upward with palms upraised. She faces forward. Her left knee and the hem of her garment are prominent; her hair may be long.

Job is old with long hair and a beard. He sits to the right of his wife. He faces forward, but with his upper body turned slightly to the right. He may be looking at the figures on the right. His arms are bent upwards with palms up. He may be receiving something from the figure to his right. He wears a gown and his large knees are prominent.
A group of four(?) gowned figures stand to the left of Job's wife. They appear to be facing forward and to the right. They may be holding gifts for Job and his wife.

A group of four(?) gowned figures stand to the right of Job. They appear to be facing left. The fourth(?) figure from the right, closest to Job, seems to be bent slightly forward, head lowered. Some or all of the figures may be holding gifts for Job and his wife.
Blue washes suggest the sky.
